contentfulBlogPost.title: Improving the online renewal process of driver's licences, health cards, and photo cards

content.value: Ontario Digital Service - Improving the online renewal process of driver's licences, health cards, and photo cards
Redesigning the Renewals

Every five years, Ontarians must renew their driver‚Äôs licence and health card to maintain
their benefits.

Ontario‚Äôs online renewal platforms were meant to provide an efficient alternative to the
in-person process. Instead, the service‚Äôs incoherence and exclusion of those who do not have a driver's licence left thousands of users frustrated and confused.

I was part of an ambitious project to redesign Ontario‚Äôs renewal experience for its over 5
million annual users.¬≠¬≠¬≠
Project Info
As a product designer, I worked in a small but effective team of five: our lab leader
Xiaopu Fung
, lead designer
Sukhi Chuhan
, fellow product designer
Emily Louie
, and prototype developers
Muiz Sohani
and
Niya Xu

description.en-US: Laptop with pen and lightbulb

content.value: Role:
Product designer

description.en-US: Four avatars linked together

content.value: Team:
One lab leader, one lead designer, two product designers, two prototype developers

description.en-US: Miro, Balsamiq, Figma, and React logos

content.value: Tools:
Miro, Balsamiq, Figma, and React

description.en-US: Calendar with checkmarks on it

content.value: Timeline:
Five weekly sprints
Within the Kitchener-Waterloo lab of the Ontario Digital Service, we conducted most of our projects in a series of 4-6 adapted Google sprints.

Mondays were focused on user research, Tuesdays and Wednesdays on prototyping, Thursdays on user testing, and Fridays on presenting our findings. To ensure thorough and clear communication, every day began with a stand-up and ended with a check-in.
Monday:
Sprint planning
Co-design
Tech research
User recruitment
Tuesday and Wednesday:
Visual mockups
Development
Create interview script and consent forms
Thursday:
User interview
Test prototype
Consolidate findings
Friday:
Show n' tell
Prototype revisions
Retrospective analysis
Defining Key Pain Points

During our team's initial meetings with the current stakeholders of the renewal platforms, we were informed that on each of the platforms, there was a Rate Our Service form that users could fill and submit.

Seeing that analyzing this direct and honest feedback would be one of the best ways for our team could begin to empathize with the frustrations of these users, our team seized this opportunity and efficiently categorized over
1,593 submissions
based on topic and frequency.
Our team then identified the most prominent complaints and focused our future redesign efforts on amending these pain points.
Gather Data from Platforms

description.en-US: Screenshot of the Rate our Service process that is available in the footer and at the completion of ServiceOntario renewal processes.

content.value: Analyze Feedback

description.en-US: Three people with speech bubbles above their head

content.value: 1,593 feedback submissions
Identify Pain Points

description.en-US: A magnifying glass focused on a exclamation mark

content.value: 3 pain points identified
Turning Suffering Into Solutions
From our discussions with subject matter experts and analysis of raw user feedback, our team diagnosed three major issues with the current service:

title.en-US: Pain Point Grid - Turning Suffering Into Solutions

description.en-US: A mockup of how confusing the ServiceOntario home page was with conflicting titles and call to action buttons in the same viewport.

content.value: Difficult
to find the appropriate service

‚ÄúThe system only works if you are renewing both [of your cards] at the same time. This means I have to go to a ServiceOntario centre for my health card just because I do not drive. I'm very disappointed."
‚ÄúIf you did not click the correct link at first, it was very difficult to find the option to renew just your driver's licence and not your health card.‚Äù

description.en-US: A file folder, file, and simplified people surrounding a globe

content.value: Combine the standalone and integrated services into a universal renewal service

description.en-US: A mockup of one of the vague errors that were presented to the user if their credentials were deemed invalid for renewal

content.value: Can‚Äôt understand
why they cannot complete the process
"After I entered my driver's licence information, I was told I was ineligible
without indication of the reason.
If I am considered ineligible to renew online,
please tell me why.
"My renewal was denied and I was
not given any reason
besides 'you're not eligible'. I think the government owes
more explanation
when it denies a service to a citizen."

description.en-US: Boxes connected with arrows to symbolize a cohesive process

content.value: Explain the reason of all errors and clearly outline next steps

description.en-US: A mockup that exhibits an example of the extraneous information the user was frequently prompted to enter in the renewal process

content.value: Redundant
and
convoluted
text and questions
"Had to enter my name thrice and address at twice after I had already selected that there have been no changes. Very annoying!"
‚ÄúIt wasn't clear on the site when I need to get a new photo in-person. A line of added text on this topic in the instructions would be useful.‚Äù

description.en-US: Four arrows shrinking a box to symbolize reduction

content.value: Reduce the repetitive input of information and simplify language
Understanding the User and Project

title.en-US: PROCESS - Improving the online renewal process of driver's licences, health cards, and photo cards

description.en-US: A GIF of a mockup that our team created during our redesign of ServiceOntario's renewal process.
View the complete research process including site audit, journey maps, premortem, stakeholder analysis, and jurisdictional analysis here.

content.value: Understanding the User

Simply knowing about what struggles the user experiences in the current renewal process is insufficient to successfully redesign a whole service. Thus, our team further familiarized ourselves with the problem space.
Site Audit
It doesn't matter how good your service is if users cannot find it.

Thus, to ease the difficult process of finding the appropriate service, the first question we asked ourselves was: how are users arriving to the service? To answer this, we conducted a high-level site audit to visualize how users navigated to the current renewal platforms.

Evidently, the amount of links and call-to-action buttons spread across seven different pages was disorientating even for our team! When our team created a solution, we would need to amend this issue.
Meet Our Personas üëã
This project was unique since we were not trying to target a narrow, specific category of users  - our designs had to accommodate for the needs of almost all Ontarians.

To represent the diversity of our user base, we created four basic personas. For each one, our team not only integrated complexities into their characteristics such as colour blindness, unfamiliarity with technology, and travel circumstances, but also into their user journeys based on the pain points observed earlier.

description.en-US: The artificially generated face that represents our persona of Deepika

content.value: Deepika
a tech-savvy millenial and international student
wants to renew their driver‚Äôs licence

description.en-US: The artificially generated face that represents our persona of Barbara

content.value: Barbara
older individual who is unfamiliar with technology and lives in a remote location
wants to renew their driver‚Äôs licence and health card

description.en-US: The artificially generated face that represents our persona of Jacob

content.value: Jacob
young adult with deuteranopia, a green colour-blindness
only wants to renew their health card

description.en-US: The artificially generated face that represents our persona of Joe

content.value: Joe
returning from his winter vacation in Florida
was pulled over by the police and fined since his driver‚Äôs licence was expired
Empathy Maps

During our analysis of the personas' thoughts, feelings, and actions throughout the renewal process, our team attempted to realistically represent their journeys by completing the renewal process with their complexities.

Whether it was disconnecting our internet halfway through the process to empathize with Barbara "losing connection" or simulating Jacob's deuteranopia with a webpage extension, this allowed our team to asses the pains and gains of their users with greater accuracy.
Journey Maps
With a greater understanding of how the user navigates, interacts, and feels during their renewal process, our team simplified each user's journey into three or four main steps.
We then integrated our findings from our site audit, personas, and empathy maps  together to identify key characteristics and events within each user's renewal experience.

From how the user discovered that their card expiry dates were approaching to how they inputted in their card information, these details enabled our team to recognize additional opportunities for improvement.
Job Stories

To reduce our assumptions and direct our focus onto the context and motivation behind users' decisions, I then created several job stories to further recognize the forces that users may experience in various situations.
Understanding the Project
Our team also ensured that we understood the technical requirements of our redesign and the expectations of our stakeholders during our engagement.
Premortem

To provide an opportunity for stakeholders and team members to openly speak about any weaknesses, failures, or reservations they might have before we undertake a project, our team facilitated a project premortem. Not only did this allow us to collaboratively recognize plausible reasons for the project‚Äôs failure, but it then enabled us to start planning for how to alter these factors to best improve the project's chances of success.
Stakeholder Analysis

Within a problem space with so many legal complexities and government ministries to consider, it was essential for our team to collaborate with product owners to understand the stakeholders involved with this project.

By grouping and mapping them according to their levels of participation, interest, and influence in the project, our team was able to determine how best to involve and communicate with each of these stakeholder groups throughout our engagement.

title.en-US: Miro - SO Renewals Stakeholder Analysis and Power/Interest Chart

content.value: Analyzing Other Jurisdictions

Especially with the narrow time frame of our team's weekly sprint iterations, our team optimized the use of our resources by identifying the strengths of other renewal services to later integrate into our designs.

title.en-US: Airtable Embed - SO Renewals Jurisdictional Analysis

content.value: Defining the Challenge

Considering how one of our product owner's primary concerns when approaching this project was that our redesign's scope would be too large, our team approached our problem definition with a divergent and convergent thinking process.
How Might We's
From our initial research, my fellow product designer and I ideated a diverse set of solutions to users' current problems.

title.en-US: Miro - SO Renewals How Might We's

content.value: Whether it was further improving the effectiveness of help modals, reassuring the user of the information they input, or optimizing the Ontario.ca topic page's representation of renewal services, this divergence in our brainstorming then allowed us to converge upon a single problem statement:
Problem Statement
We have observed that the ServiceOntario online renewal flows are
not meeting user needs,
which is causing low completion rates, negative user feedback, inclusion concerns, and low uptake on digital services.
How might we design a one-window digital renewal transaction flow that
promotes usability and inclusion
by reducing time on task and increasing positive feedback on eligibility?
Starting With the Best Case Scenario

Especially with a renewal service, there is certainly no lack in the number of paths, exceptions, and errors that a user can take to encounter along their journey. Thus, we first highlighted the requirements that a user would need to meet to successfully renew their driver's licence or health card.
Then, to emphasize an easy and effortless central flow in our redesign, we identified the key set of steps that a user would take to successfully renew their driver's licence or health card.

description.en-US: A user journey map of an ideal renewal process

content.value: Creating Our Concept
Ideation
Our team individually sketched user flows and interfaces in five-minute brainstorming sessions and presented our designs to the group.

title.en-US: Creating Our Concept - Miro User Flow

content.value: Consolidating Our Ideas
We then combined the strengths of our ideas into a final user flow that represented our team‚Äôs vision of the redesigned renewal service‚Äôs golden path.
Low Fidelity Prototype
With our lead designer, my fellow product designer and I then created a low-fidelity Balsamiq prototype that simulated this ideated flow.
Clarity, Clarity, Clarity
Equipped with a low-fidelity prototype of our redesigned renewal platform's ideal user journey, my fellow designers and I traveled to the heart of downtown Toronto to conduct guerilla user testing.

title.en-US: Grid With Icons - Testing Our Assumptions

Lead designer and two product designers

As a product designer, I led guerilla testing sessions to gather users' direct and honest opinions about our prototype!

content.value: Our team then synthesized our findings into prototype iterations to consider in next week's sprint. Here are some highlights:

title.en-US: Old to New - Clarity, Clarity, Clarity (Ensure the user is informed before they begin)

content.value: Ensure the user is informed before they begin

title.en-US: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (OLD) Ensure the User is Informed Before They Begin

en-US.fileName: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (OLD) Ensure the User is Informed Before They Begin.svg

content.value: ‚ÄúI would want to know requirements, fees, what they need to have out, possibly how long it will take to complete.‚Äù
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to go through the whole process just to realize I don‚Äôt have the funds to pay for my renewal‚Äù
Show fees for each renewal type
Display duration of transaction
Exhibit what information the user will need

title.en-US: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (NEW) Ensure the User is Informed Before They Begin

en-US.fileName: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (NEW) Ensure the User is Informed Before They Begin.svg

title.en-US: Old to New - Clarity, Clarity, Clarity (Remove ambiguous language)

content.value: Remove ambiguous language

title.en-US: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (OLD) Remove Ambiguous Language
Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (OLD) Remove Ambiguous Language

content.value: ‚ÄúWhat is a trillium number?‚Äù (not a single user knew what or where their trillium number was)
‚ÄúWhat 9 characters is this referring to? Is that my social insurance number?‚Äù
Replaced government terminology with description
Always display the number‚Äôs location on the card

title.en-US: Clarity, Clarity, Clarity - (NEW) Remove Ambiguous Language

content.value: Designing Alternate Paths

For our second iteration, our team considered a more realistic approach for our redesign - it was time to integrate in error states and eligibility complexities. Thus, we once again collaborated with stakeholders to ensure that our solution would be able to encompass all of the necessary technical requirements of the previous platform.
Extending a Helping Hand

It was time for our second round of guerilla user testing sessions! This time, having gained more confidence and practice for the user research methodology, my fellow product designer and I went by ourselves.

title.en-US: Grid With Icons - Checking Our Clarifications

As a product designer, I led guerilla testing sessions to gather users' direct and honest opinions about our prototype!

content.value: Equipped with a much more comprehensive prototype, we were able to gather a richer understanding of the end users' reactions to our newly designed ineligibility errors and transaction summary page.

title.en-US: Old to New - Extending a Helping Hand (Include next steps after errors)

content.value: Include next steps after errors

title.en-US: Extending a Helping Hand - (OLD) Include Next Steps After Errors

en-US.fileName: Extending a Helping Hand - (OLD) Include Next Steps After Errors.svg

content.value: ‚ÄúOkay so I‚Äôm clearly ineligible, but could you give me a bit more explanation on next steps now?‚Äù
‚ÄúPlease show more next steps in the error, I would not not how to proceed from here.‚Äù
Direct them to the nearest location to complete the in-person process
Provide an alternate path to continue their online renewal

title.en-US: Extending a Helping Hand - (NEW) Include Next Steps After Errors
Old to New - Extending a Helping Hand (Allow users to edit previously entered details)

content.value: Allow users to edit previously entered details

title.en-US: Extending a Helping Hand - (OLD) Allow Users to Edit Previously Entered Info

content.value: ‚ÄúI should be able change the information and then hit ‚Äúsave‚Äù and come back to the review page.‚Äù
‚ÄúI should be able to edit my contact information directly on this page.‚Äù
Edit buttons allow users to fix their mistakes
Can edit contact information directly on the page

title.en-US: Extending a Helping Hand - (NEW) Allow Users to Edit Previously Entered Info

en-US.fileName: Extending a Helping Hand - (NEW) Allow Users to Edit Previously Entered Info.svg

content.value: Transitioning to High Fidelity
Halfway through our engagement, it was time for our team to translate our Balsamiq prototype to Figma.

title.en-US: Figma Prototype Embed - SO Renewals Sprint 3

content.value: Content is Key
With ten facilitations of guerilla usability testing sessions under my belt, it was time to help a developer teammate learn these key user research principles during our third round of user testing!

title.en-US: Grid With Icons - Content is Key

Prototype

title.en-US: Compact Image Grid - Content is Key

content.value: Once again, one of our dominant issues was a lack of clarity in the content used in our design. Now with a month of experience in the problem space, our team likely had become so familiar with government terminology that we had not considered how confusing its use would be to our user base.

title.en-US: ServiceOntario Renewals - Show and Tell With Figma User Comments

description.en-US: A screenshot of my presentation of user comments in our Figma prototype during our weekly show and tell presentation to stakeholders

content.value: We noted these findings, and after presenting them at our weekly show and tell, we were able to work with our content designer to implement their feedback.

title.en-US: Old to New - Content is Key (Clearer ineligibility states)

content.value: Clearer ineligibility states

title.en-US: Content is Key - (OLD) Clearer Functionality of Buttons and Links

en-US.fileName: Content is Key - (OLD) Clearer Functionality of Buttons and Links.svg

content.value: ‚ÄúThis error would greatly disappoint me, but I guess I‚Äôd just have to deal with it.‚Äù
‚ÄúCan you provide me with more explanation on why I‚Äôm not eligible for online renewal?
Specifically state the issue(s) that caused the error
Inform the user about the necessary resources they will need to complete the process

title.en-US: Content is Key - (NEW) Clearer Functionality of Buttons and Links

en-US.fileName: Content is Key - (NEW) Clearer Functionality of Buttons and Links.svg

title.en-US: Old to New - Content is Key (Describe complex terminology)

content.value: Describe complex terminology

title.en-US: Content is Key - (OLD) Describe Complex Terminology

en-US.fileName: Content is Key - (OLD) Describe Complex Terminology.svg

content.value: ‚ÄúFull class portion? That‚Äôs very ambiguous and unclear.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve had my licence for over twenty years and I‚Äôve never heard of the term ‚Äòfull class portion‚Äô before.‚Äù
Provide a detailed description with example scenarios of applicability
Supply optional links for further explanation

title.en-US: Content is Key - (NEW) Describe Complex Terminology

en-US.fileName: Content is Key - (NEW) Describe Complex Terminology.svg

content.value: Implementing Inclusivity
In our discussions at the beginning of this engagement, one of the most urgent requests brought up by stakeholders was for us to integrate the renewal of the Ontario Photo Card into the platform.

title.en-US: Half Large Image, Half Points - Implementing Inclusivity

description.en-US: A group of simplified people

content.value: Ontario photo cards help provide valid identification for over 1.5 million Ontarians who do not drive
There is currently no online platform for Ontario photo card renewals or renewal of  a health card using an Ontario photo card
This is an accessibility issue for those who are unable to access renewal centres or who need to renew their health card

Once again, our team collaborated with stakeholders to define the ideal user journey and document the complexities of the in-person renewal service to effectively translate this process into a efficient online process.
Here is our Figma prototype in our fourth weekly sprint:

title.en-US: Figma Prototype Embed - SO Renewals Sprint 4
Figma Page Embed - ServiceOntario Renewals Sprint 4

content.value: Polishing the Prototype
Though only my fellow product designer and a developer conducted this final set of guerilla user tests, I was nevertheless was instrumental in integrating the gathered feedback into our prototype.
For this iteration, our team learned the importance of taking the vertical restriction of a mobile user interface into account in our
coded prototype

title.en-US: Old to New - Polishing the Prototype (Starting above the fold)

content.value: Starting above the fold
"Where is the start button?"
Segmented information onto another page for a gentler introduction to the platform
Ensured that the 'Start' call-to-action button was visible above the fold

title.en-US: Old to New - Polishing the Prototype (Surface helpful information first)

content.value: Surface helpful information first
"I don't know where my 7 digit number on my driver's licence is"
Placed the hint image before the input field to ensure that the user views the explanation first
Results and Recommendations
Though we were unable to present our
final prototype
to the executives of the Ministry of Transportation and Ministry of Health that we were partnering with, we still were able to summarize our reasoning and display our prototype to our product owners.

description.en-US: A screenshot of my presentation of our final Figma prototype during our final show and tell to our product owners and stakeholders.

content.value: After our presentation, one of the product owners stated:

Jayden understands complex nuances quickly and thinks in a user-centric way. He is excellent at trying something, getting valuable input from real users, iterating, and documenting findings. Beyond great results, it's a pleasure to work and collaborate with him. He's a quick study and also a collaborative partner with subject matter experts.
Learning and Growing, One Project at a Time

Working in the Ontario Digital Service Kitchener-Waterloo Lab was an unforgettable experience. Not only did projects such as this allow me to exponentially grow my skillset through exposure to unique, enterprise-level opportunities, but this small but mighty team of six taught me how to enjoy every second of it!

description.en-US: A group picture of me and my five other team members at the Ontario Digital Service Kitchener-Waterloo Lab

content.value: Despite this growth, I still recognize that my designs and process are far from perfect. In the spirit of our team's weekly retrospectives, here are my three areas of future improvement:
Talk to users directly

No matter how confident I felt in my assumptions about the problem space, that's all they were - assumptions. This project reinforced my belief in the importance of user feedback to ensure that our prototype met real-world expectations and needs.

title.en-US: Lesson - Be comfortable with being uncomfortable

content.value: Be comfortable with being uncomfortable

Despite my extroversion, I remember how uncomfortable I was during our first guerilla user testing session. However, once I approached that first stranger and successfully conducted an interview, I recognized the situation as an opportunity to learn. While it will be frightening, I hope to approach future situations with a similar eagerness to explore.
Challenge my capabilities

When our team was told that we had a week to create a prototype with Balsamiq, an application that I had never used before, I knew that I was up for a challenge. After experiencing rapid growth in my skillset as a result of this short time frame, I have recognized that learning thrives in difficulty.
